concept.title: Armament
concept.shortdesc: The armament of the follows basically the same pattern found in any AAF bombardment airplane. The detailed installation varies greatly according to the tactical uses intended.

conbody.p: Safe handling and operation require thorough knowledge arid practice on this equipment, under the supervision of a competent instructor.

section.title: Bombing
section.p: The bomb bay, between the navigator s and the radio operator's compartments, has fixed ladder bomb racks which accommodate 100-lb. to 1600-lb. bombs. A special rack may he installed to carry one 2000-lb. bomb. The control system is electric and most of the system is dual wired as a precaution against damage by gunfire. Wing racks may be installed on the outer wing panels to carry 8 bombs of from 100 lb. to 300 lb., or 6 325-lb. depth charges.
Controls for operating the bomb bay doors and bomb releases are in the bombardier's compartment.
On the G and H, the bomb bay and bombing controls are in the pilot's compartment.

fig.title: Bomb bay
fig.desc: Image of four large bombs contained within the bomb bay of an airplane.

image.alt: Bomb bay of the holding four large bombs.

section.p: On the J, the bombardment controls are in both the bombardier's and pilot's compartments.
Controls in the pilot's compartment will salvo both bomb load and bomb bay tanks. (See Emergency Procedures.)
Provision is made for carrying a torpedo as an alternate bomb load. Use of the torpedo precludes bomb loads in the bomb bay, but does not limit the use of external wing racks.
Chemical spray tanks may be carried in the bomb bay and on the wing racks when necessary.

section.title: Gunnery
section.p: Gunnery equipment varies greatly in different series airplanes. They are as follows: C and D,

fig.title: C and D 50-cal nose gun
fig.desc: Image of a windowed part of an airplane with two types of large caliber machine guns.

section.p: One nose gun is mounted on the right side of the bombardier's compartment. The pilot fires this gun and the bombardier charges it. There is a type N-3B optical gunsight on the upper left side of the instrument panel.
One flexible .5fl-cal. nose gun, in a ball-and-socket mount, is directly above the bombsight window. The bombardier fires this gun, which has a ring-and-post sight.
There is an electrically powered Bendix upper turret in the radio gunner's compartment. This turret carries two fired by either the radio operator or the gunner, and has a type N-6A optical gunsight.

section.title: G
section.p: One 75-mm. cannon (type M-4) is in the tunnel beneath the left side of the pilot's compartment and fires through the nose. The pilot fires the cannon and the cannoneer loads it. There is a type N-3B optical gunsight on the left side of the pilot's instrument panel for the forward-firing guns.
Two forward-firing, are in the nose. The pilot charges and fires these guns.
There is a Bendix upper turret in the radio gunner's compartment. It carries two , fired by either the radio operator or the gunner, and has a type N-6A optical gunsight.
A few modified G's carry waist guns J blister guns, and one tail gun.

section.title: H
section.p: One 75-mm, cannon (type T-13) is in the tunnel beneath the left side of the pilot's compartment and fires through the nose. The pilot fires the cannon and the cannoneer loads it. A type N-3B optical gunsight for the forward-firing guns is on the left side of the pilot's instrument panel.
Four forward-firing, are in the nose section. The pilot fires these guns, which are charged in the navigator-cannoneer's compartment.
Two or four fixed are mounted in blisters on each side of the plane. The cannoneer charges these guns and the pilot fires them.
A Bendix upper turret, in the aft portion of the cannoneer's compartment, carries two , fired by the engineer, and has an N-6A gunsight.
Two flexible in Plexiglas windows, one at each side of the fuselage aft of the bomb bay, are fired by the radio operator. They have ring-and-post sights.
A Bell model M-7 electric-hydraulic turret with two and a type N-8 gunsight is in the tail. A tail gunner operates this turret.

section.title: J
section.p: There is one or two forward-fixing, nose gun. The bombardier charges this gun and the pilot fires it. The bombardier fires one flexible in the nose.
Four fixed are installed in blisters, two on each side of the fuselage. The cannoneer charges these guns and the pilot fires them.
A type N-3B optical gunsight governs the forward-firing guns.
A Bendix upper turret, in the aft portion of the cannoneer's compartment, carries two , fired by the engineer, and has an N-6A gunsight.
Two flexible in Plexiglas windows, one at each side of the fuselage aft of the bomb bay, are fired by the radio operator. They have ring-and-bead or optical sights.
A Bell model M-7 electric-hydraulic turret with two and a type N-8 gunsight is in the tail and is operated by a tail gunner.
